results.title: Unstable elements
results.creator_credit: Newsreel Collective, Gillian Slovo, Andy Metcalf and Paul Morrison
results.brief_description: Using revealing interviews with prominent scientists, and extraordinary newsreels from the 1940s and 1950s, “Unstable Elements” traces the history of nuclear Britain. Combining several stories in one film, this film also examines - through its fictional part - the way the tunnel vision of the atomic scientists is reflected in family life. A film for a wide audience.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Newsreel Collective, Gillian Slovo, Andy Metcalf and Paul Morrison

results.title: Unseen horizons
results.creator_credit: Associated British-Pathe, Terry Ashwood and Bernard Till
results.brief_description: A complete primary, secondary and specialised vocational educational system for the blind is maintained in Great Britain by the Royal National Institute for the Blind. All types of schools provided are shown.

results.title: Unseen harvest
results.creator_credit: Africa Film Service, British Information Services and Jim Northcott
results.brief_description: The Salamawe training school for the blind in Uganda. Blind students are taught to become farmers, and instruction from sighted Africans is given in many branches of land cultivation and in the handling of farm equipment. Rope and basket making, athletics and music, are enjoyed by the students.

results.title: Unseen enemies
results.creator_credit: Shell Film Unit, Stuart Legg and Michael Clarke
results.brief_description: Shows the ravages of such diseases as leprosy, malaria, elephantiasis, yaws, yellow fever in various countries and what is being done, mainly through the World Health Organisation to eradicate them.

results.title: Unseen Bean
results.brief_description: Features two episodes of the popular Mr Bean sketches: “Back to school Mr Bean” sees the bumbling Mr Bean wreaking havoc in an art class, a judo lesson and a science class. It is however Mr Bean’s much loved Mini-minor which comes off second best. No-one in their right minds would let Mr. Bean loose with a pair of scissors, but in “Hair by Mr. Bean of London” he does exactly that. His perfect day of cutting and slashing is topped off when Teddy wins a prize at the fete. However at the train station Mr Bean is once again a victim of circumstance.

results.brief_description: Yang Fudong’s five-channel video installation, ‘The Coloured Sky: New Women II’ (2014), marks an aesthetic departure from his signature output on 35mm black and white film to vivid colour.

results.title: Unmarried mothers
results.creator_credit: Granada International Productions, Elaine Grand and Michael Grigsby
results.brief_description: A report on illegitimacy in Britain. Eight unmarried mothers are interviewed before and after the birth of their babies. They talk about contraception, abortion, adoption and the problems they face in society and in supporting a baby. The work of the National Council of the Unmarried Mother and Child, Mothers and Baby Homes and the social worker is shown. Narrated by Douglas Keay.

results.title: Unknown pleasures = Ren Xiao yao [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Office Kitano, Lumen Films, E-Pictures, T-Mark, Hu Tong Communications, Bitters End (Unknown pleasures)--Beijing Film Academy, Radiant Advertising Company, Shozo Ichiyama, Li Kit-ming and Jia Zhang-ke
results.brief_description: Unknown pleasures: Set in the provincial Chinese city of Datong in 2001, the story follows the lives of two 19 year-old unemployed and disenchanted friends Bin Bin (Zhao Wei Wei) and Xiao Ji (Wu Qiong) who spend their days aimlessly wandering around dreaming of ways of escaping their meaningless and boring existences. China, with its rapidly changing political and economical role in the world, finds itself being drawn into the web of globalisation and the World Trade Organisation and televisions all over China are blasting out the message of change to the Chinese population. However, for the alienated Bin Bin and Xiao Ji, it is the day-to-day survival that counts. Poignant and slow-moving. Cast also includes Zhao Tao, Zhou Qing Feng. “Xiao Wu”: Jia Zhang-Ke’s directorial debut low-budget film shot on 16mm with non-professional actors about a small time thief and pickpocket, Xiao Wu, operating in a small provincial town at a time of immense social change in China. Xiao Wu finds it difficult to adapt to the new China and worse still, that he is becoming an outcast facing rejection from a potential relationship and even his own parents. A tragi-comedy. Cast includes Wang Hong Wei, Hao Hong Jian, Zuo Bai Tao, Ma Jin Rei, Liu Jun Ying. Director of photography for both these beautifully directed films is Yu Lik Wai.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Office Kitano, Lumen Films, E-Pictures, T-Mark, Hu Tong Communications, Bitters End (Unknown pleasures)—Beijing Film Academy, Radiant Advertising Company, Shozo Ichiyama, Li Kit-ming and Jia Zhang-ke

results.title: Unknown Island
results.brief_description:
Two Pacific explorers go sailing and encounter an unknown island. When they meet the tribal people and do not understand them, they procure a piece of land and build a dwelling.

An animated short entered to “Create a Stamp Story” section of ACMI’s ‘Screen It’ media making competition for Primary Schools.
